problems.title: T+1 Settlement Transition Complexity and Cross-Border FX Mismatch
problems.description: The global transition to T+1 (trade date plus one day) settlement is creating significant operational challenges for market participants, particularly in cross-border transactions. The fundamental problem is that while securities are moving to T+1 settlement, foreign exchange transactions remain on T+2, creating a timing mismatch that increases settlement risk and funding requirements. The compression of the settlement window from T+2 to T+1 reduces available operational time by 83%, from approximately 12 hours to just 2 hours for critical post-trade processes. This creates cascading effects across trade matching, affirmation, allocation, and funding processes. International firms face the greatest challenges, as they must coordinate across multiple time zones with very limited windows to resolve exceptions. Settlement failures are increasing, particularly for ADRs where underlying foreign shares remain on T+2, and ETFs which now account for up to 40% of all settlement failures. The industry faces an estimated $5-10 billion in increased operational costs and working capital requirements during the transition period.
problems.summary: The shift to T+1 settlement creates operational bottlenecks due to 83% time compression and FX/securities settlement cycle mismatches, particularly impacting cross-border transactions.

barriers: FX market settlement cycle unchanged at T+2

problems.title: Central Counterparty Systemic Risk Concentration and Recovery Framework Uncertainty
problems.description: Post-2008 regulatory reforms mandated central clearing for standardized derivatives, concentrating counterparty risk in a small number of Central Counterparties (CCPs). While this reduced bilateral counterparty risk, it created new systemic concerns around CCP resilience and recovery. CCPs are now designated as systemically important financial market infrastructures (SIFMIs), yet significant uncertainty remains about recovery and resolution mechanisms. The default waterfall structure shifts losses disproportionately from CCPs to clearing members, with CCP capital contributions (skin-in-the-game) typically being only 1-3x smaller than the guarantee fund. This creates moral hazard concerns as equity holders can maintain their interest while clearing members bear losses. Liquidity risk is particularly acute during market stress when CCPs must exchange settlements on a mark-to-market basis. The concentration in a few dominant CCPs means that the failure of even one could trigger cascading failures across global financial markets. Non-default losses (NDL) such as cyber attacks or operational failures present additional challenges not adequately addressed by current frameworks.
problems.summary: Mandatory central clearing has concentrated systemic risk in a few CCPs, while recovery and resolution frameworks remain inadequate, particularly regarding loss allocation and liquidity risk during market stress.

problems.title: Market Data Fragmentation, Cost Burden, and Lack of Consolidated Tape
problems.description: Capital markets suffer from fragmented and expensive market data infrastructure, particularly in Europe where no consolidated tape exists for equities. Market participants must purchase data from multiple trading venues, each with complex licensing terms, resulting in duplicative costs estimated at billions of dollars annually. In the US, while consolidated tapes exist, they are criticized for latency and costs, with proprietary data feeds from exchanges commanding premium pricing. This creates a two-tiered market where only well-resourced participants can afford comprehensive market data, disadvantaging smaller firms and retail investors. The fragmentation also complicates best execution obligations and regulatory surveillance. Despite years of regulatory discussion, particularly around the EU's MiFID II requirements for a consolidated tape, implementation has stalled due to commercial interests of incumbent exchanges. The lack of affordable, consolidated data also hampers innovation in analytics and AI applications that require comprehensive market views.
problems.summary: Market data remains fragmented and expensive, with no consolidated tape in Europe and high costs globally, creating information asymmetry and disadvantaging smaller market participants.

problems.title: Legacy Technology Infrastructure and Critical COBOL Skills Shortage in Market Systems
problems.description: Critical capital markets infrastructure continues to run on legacy mainframe systems with COBOL code, some dating back 40+ years. These systems process trillions of dollars in transactions daily, yet the workforce capable of maintaining them is rapidly retiring. The average COBOL programmer is around 60 years old, with approximately 10% retiring each year. Universities stopped teaching COBOL in the 1980s, creating a 40-year gap in new talent. An estimated 240 billion lines of COBOL remain in operation, with 5 billion new lines added annually. COBOL supports 95% of ATM transactions and 43% of banking systems. Financial institutions face a critical knowledge crisis as the experts who built and understand these systems retire, taking undocumented institutional knowledge with them. Modernization efforts are complicated by the interconnected nature of these systems, regulatory requirements for stability, and the massive cost and risk of migration. Many major institutions have zero plans for full mainframe retirement by 2035, indicating the problem will persist for decades.

problems.title: Latency Arbitrage and High-Frequency Trading Market Fairness Concerns
problems.description: Latency arbitrage - the practice of profiting from microsecond-level delays in information flow between markets - raises significant fairness concerns in capital markets. Studies show latency arbitrage races account for approximately 20% of trading volume in major indices, with global equity market latency arbitrage rents estimated at $5 billion annually. The practice is highly concentrated, with the top three firms capturing over 55% of arbitrage profits. This creates a two-tiered market where sophisticated, well-resourced participants systematically extract value from slower traders. Research indicates latency arbitrage adds approximately 0.5 basis points to trading costs, increasing expenses for large institutional funds by about 17%. The arms race for speed drives billions in investment in non-productive infrastructure - specialized cables, microwave towers, and co-location facilities - that provides no societal benefit beyond enabling faster trading. Critics argue this creates 'phantom liquidity' that disappears during market stress, as evidenced during the 2010 Flash Crash. While exchanges have introduced mechanisms like speed bumps, the fundamental asymmetry persists.
problems.summary: Latency arbitrage extracts approximately $5 billion annually from markets, concentrated among a few HFT firms, creating fairness concerns and driving wasteful infrastructure investment.

problems.title: Cross-Border Settlement Interoperability and Fragmented National Infrastructure
problems.description: Global capital markets suffer from fragmented national settlement infrastructures that do not interoperate effectively, creating friction and risk in cross-border transactions. Each jurisdiction maintains its own Central Securities Depository (CSD), with different technical standards, operating hours, legal frameworks, and settlement cycles. This fragmentation requires complex correspondent banking networks and custodian chains to bridge systems, adding layers of cost and counterparty risk. Settlement typically requires pre-positioning of assets and funding in multiple jurisdictions, increasing capital requirements. The move to T+1 settlement in some markets while others remain on T+2 exacerbates these challenges. International investors face higher costs and operational complexity compared to domestic participants. Efforts like TARGET2-Securities in Europe have achieved regional harmonization, but global interoperability remains elusive. Emerging markets often have even more fragmented and less reliable infrastructure, limiting their integration into global capital flows. The lack of standardized messaging and data formats further complicates automation and straight-through processing.
problems.summary: Fragmented national settlement systems create friction in cross-border transactions, requiring complex intermediary chains and pre-positioning of assets across jurisdictions.

problems.title: Post-Trade Digital Transformation Barriers and DLT Adoption Challenges
problems.description: Capital markets post-trade infrastructure faces significant barriers to digital transformation, particularly in adopting distributed ledger technology (DLT) and tokenization. While DLT promises to revolutionize settlement by enabling real-time, atomic delivery-versus-payment and eliminating reconciliation needs, adoption has been slow and fragmented. Pilots remain isolated, with limited interoperability between different blockchain platforms or with legacy systems. Regulatory uncertainty persists around digital asset classification, smart contract enforceability, and finality of settlement on distributed ledgers. The industry lacks standards for tokenization, creating fragmentation as each initiative develops proprietary approaches. Incumbent infrastructure providers have limited incentive to cannibalize existing business models. The massive investments already made in current systems create path dependencies. Technical challenges around scalability, privacy, and integration with existing processes remain unsolved at enterprise scale. Meanwhile, the opportunity cost grows as competitors in other sectors advance digital transformation more rapidly.

problems.title: AI and Data Infrastructure Readiness Deficiencies for Market Automation
problems.description: Capital markets infrastructure faces significant challenges in achieving AI readiness due to foundational data quality and governance issues. For AI initiatives to succeed, data must be highly available, discoverable, clean, and clearly labeled with rich metadata. However, most market infrastructure operators have fragmented data estates accumulated over decades, with inconsistent formats, missing metadata, unclear lineage, and inadequate governance. Legacy batch processing architectures cannot support the real-time data flows required for AI-powered automation. Data privacy and compliance requirements (GDPR, financial regulations) create additional complexity for AI training and deployment. Integration of legacy systems with modern data platforms presents significant costs and technical hurdles. Many organizations lack the talent to bridge traditional financial technology and modern data science. Without addressing these foundational data issues, AI initiatives in surveillance, compliance automation, and predictive settlement will continue to underperform or fail entirely.

problems.title: Procyclical Margin Requirements and Liquidity Spirals During Market Stress
problems.description: Central counterparties and exchanges employ risk-based margin models that increase collateral requirements as market volatility rises. While prudent from a risk management perspective, this procyclicality can amplify market stress by forcing participants to post additional collateral precisely when liquidity is most constrained. During the March 2020 COVID crisis, CCPs issued margin calls exceeding $300 billion in a single week, contributing to market dislocations. Participants who cannot meet margin calls face position liquidations, further driving prices in the wrong direction. The timing of margin calls - often overnight or intraday - can create operational challenges and forced selling. Smaller market participants are disproportionately affected as they have less buffer capacity. While regulators have mandated anti-procyclicality measures, the fundamental tension between risk sensitivity and stability remains unresolved. The interaction between margin requirements across multiple CCPs and asset classes can create complex, hard-to-predict liquidity dynamics during stress events.
problems.summary: Risk-based margin models increase collateral requirements during volatility, amplifying market stress and creating liquidity spirals when participants cannot meet margin calls.

problems.title: Trading Platform Reliability Incidents and Exchange Outage Frequency
problems.description: Major stock exchanges and trading platforms have experienced an increasing frequency of technical outages and reliability incidents, causing market disruptions, trading halts, and economic losses. Notable incidents include multi-hour outages at major exchanges, failed market opens, and data feed disruptions affecting price discovery. These incidents stem from the increasing complexity of trading systems, the challenge of maintaining legacy components alongside modern systems, capacity constraints during volume spikes, and the difficulty of testing systems under realistic conditions. The interconnected nature of modern markets means that an outage at one venue can cascade to affect liquidity and pricing across multiple markets. Market participants face uncertainty and potential losses when they cannot execute trades or receive accurate market data. Regulatory scrutiny has increased, with exchanges facing investigations and fines for operational failures. The competitive pressure to add features and reduce latency can conflict with reliability objectives.
problems.summary: Stock exchanges and trading platforms experience increasing outages due to system complexity, legacy integration challenges, and capacity constraints, causing market-wide disruptions.

problems.title: Cybersecurity Threats to Critical Market Infrastructure
problems.description: Capital markets infrastructure faces escalating cybersecurity threats from nation-state actors, organized crime, and hacktivists. As systemically important financial market infrastructures, exchanges, CCPs, and CSDs are high-value targets where successful attacks could cause widespread market disruption. Threats include ransomware attacks that could halt trading operations, data breaches exposing sensitive trading information and positions, manipulation of market data feeds, and attacks on the integrity of settlement systems. The increasing adoption of cloud services and APIs expands the attack surface. Legacy systems often cannot support modern security controls. The interconnected nature of market infrastructure means that a breach at one participant can cascade to affect others. Skilled cybersecurity talent is scarce and expensive. Regulatory requirements are increasing but may lag behind evolving threats. Third-party and supply chain risks add complexity, as market infrastructure depends on numerous vendors and service providers. The potential for AI-enhanced attacks raises the sophistication of threats faster than defenses can adapt.
